c19vaxdaTextEn.textdesc: Welcome. This website is here to help people in Canada make informed decisions about Covid-19 vaccines. You can use it to make a decision about a vaccine for yourself or for your child.

We need to know a little bit of information about you/your child to give you the right data. We use this information to:
  • help determine which vaccines are available to you/your child
  • estimate your/your child's risk of getting Covid-19
  • estimate what might happen to you/your child if you/your child got Covid-19
Are you/Is your child eligible for a vaccine because: (optional, check all that apply)

There are currently 4 approved vaccines available in Canada. In this decision aid, you can compare 2 options. This means you can compare any vaccine to no vaccine, or you can compare two vaccines against each other.

What do you want to compare? (choose two)
Not sure which vaccine(s) are available to you? Check this box and we will show you the information for your most likely option, based on your age, province/territory, and eligibility.

Important: Different vaccines were tested with different groups of people, at different times, in different places, and with different variants of concern circulating. This makes them hard to compare to each other. We will show you the data from the different trials for each these vaccines side-by-side, but please remember: this is not an apples-to-apples comparison. These vaccines have not been tested against each other, so we don't actually know for sure how they stack up against each other.
Choose the character that looks most like you/your child.

c19vaxdaTextFr.textdesc: Déterminer le type de vaccin recommandé contre la COVID-19
Les vaccins contre la COVID-19

Bienvenue. Ce site Web a pour objectif d'aider la population canadienne à prendre en toute connaissance de cause des décisions concernant la vaccination contre la COVID-19. Il vous permettra de vous informer sur le choix de vaccin pour vous ou pour votre enfant.
À propos de vous/votre enfant
À propos de vous/votre enfant

Afin de vous fournir les bonnes informations, nous avons besoin d’en savoir un peu plus sur vous/votre enfant. Ces informations ne sont utilisées que pour:
  • vous aider à déterminer quels sont les vaccins envisageables pour vous/votre enfant
  • estimer votre risque/le risque de votre enfant de contracter la COVID-19
  • estimer ce qui pourrait arriver à vous/votre enfant si vous/votre enfant contractiez la COVID-19
Votre province ou territoire:
Votre âge/L'âge de votre enfant (en années):
Êtes-vous/votre enfant éligible pour un vaccin pour les raisons suivantes: (optionel, Cochez toutes les options possibles)
Choisir les options à comparer

Actuellement, il y a 4 vaccins approuvés disponibles au Canada. Cette aide à la décision vous permettra de comparer deux options. Vous pourrez par exemple comparer un vaccin à aucun vaccin, ou encore comparer deux vaccins l'un à l'autre.

Que souhaitez-vous comparer? (choisissez-en deux)

Vous ne savez pas quel(s) vaccin(s) vous pouvez recevoir ? Cochez cette case et nous vous présenterons les informations relatives à l'option la plus appropriée pour vous, en fonction de votre âge, de votre province/territoire et de votre admissibilité.

Important: Les différents vaccins ont été testés sur différents groupes de population, à différents stades, dans différents pays, et avec différentes souches du virus en circulation. Il est par conséquent complexe de les comparer les uns aux autres. Nous vous présenterons les données provenant des différents essais pour chacun des vaccins en parallèle, mais n'oubliez pas : il ne s'agit pas de procéder à une comparaison exhaustive. Ces vaccins n'ont pas été testés entre eux, nous ne pouvons pas affirmer avec certitude qu'ils se valent les uns les autres.

c19vaxdaPfizerEn.vaxcontentdesc:
The Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine was approved by Health Canada on December 9, 2020 for people 16 years old and older. It was approved by Health Canada on May 5, 2021 for children aged 12 to 15 years old.

It is a 2-dose messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine. Messenger RNA means the vaccine gives your body instructions to make a part of the Covid-19 virus that is harmless on its own. Your body then learns to fight off that part of the virus. If your body encounters the full virus later, it knows how to destroy the part it already recognizes. Without its missing part, the virus cannot survive.

Messenger RNA does not last in the body. The vaccine does not change your DNA.
"Incidence of Covid‑19 per 1,000 person‑years of follow‑up in participants without evidence of prior infection with SARS‑CoV‑2, up to seven days after the administration of Dose 2 of the vaccine"
About the vaccine & how it works

c19vaxdaPfizerEn.vaxcontentdesc:
The Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine is a 2-dose messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine. Messenger RNA means the vaccine gives your body instructions for how to make a part of the Covid-19 virus (the "spike protein" on the outside of the virus) that is harmless on its own. Your body makes that harmless part of the virus. When your immune system runs into that new thing that it does not recognize as being part of you, your immune system figures out how to destroy the part. When the immune system has fought off the part once, if it encounters the full virus later, it knows how to destroy the part it already recognizes. Without its missing part, the virus cannot survive.

Messenger RNA does not last in the body. Once your immune system has learned to recognize the virus, it doesn't need the messenger RNA anymore. The vaccine does not change your DNA.

This vaccine requires two doses to provide full protection, because your immune system may need a reminder to make sure it recognizes and knows how to fight off the virus.
With no vaccine, you do not have this additional protection.

Messenger RNA means the vaccine gives your body instructions for how to make a part of the Covid-19 virus (the "spike protein" on the outside of the virus) that is harmless on its own. Your body makes that harmless part of the virus. When your immune system runs into that new thing that it does not recognize as being part of you, your immune system figures out how to destroy the part. When the immune system has fought off the part once, if it encounters the full virus later, it knows how to destroy the part it already recognizes. Without its missing part, the virus cannot survive.

Messenger RNA does not last in the body. Once your immune system has learned to recognize the virus, it doesn't need the messenger RNA anymore. The vaccine does not change your DNA.

This vaccine requires two doses to provide full protection, because your immune system may need a reminder to make sure it recognizes and knows how to fight off the virus.
Health Canada's page showing all the scientific information about the vaccine
How the vaccine was developed and made

How and where the vaccine was tested

The Pfizer vaccine was tested among those 16 years and older from [date] to [date] in [places]. The people in the study were people aged 16 years and older. The group included a broad mix of people. About half were male and about half were female. The group included people who were over 65 years old, who were pregnant, who had chronic illnesses, as well as many people who were younger, not pregnant, and who had no chronic illnesses. There were 36533 people in the study in total: 18196 who were randomly chosen to get two doses of the vaccine.

Then, the vaccine was tested among people 12 to 15 years old from [date] to [date] in [places]. In the second study, the people in the study were 12 to 15 years old. ZZZ ADD MORE DETAILS

The other 18337 people were randomly chosen to get two doses of a needle filled with sterile salt water. The needle filled with salt water is called a placebo. The people in the study were not told until after the study was over whether they had gotten the vaccine or the placebo. The people who had gotten the placebo had the chance to get the vaccine after the study was over.

The Pfizer vaccine was tested among those 16 years and older from [date] to [date] in [places]. The people in the study were people aged 16 years and older. The group included a broad mix of people. About half were male and about half were female. The group included people who were over 65 years old, who were pregnant, who had chronic illnesses, as well as many people who were younger, not pregnant, and who had no chronic illnesses. There were 36533 people in the study in total: 18196 who were randomly chosen to get two doses of the vaccine, and 18337 who were randomly chosen to get two doses of a needle filled with sterile salt water. The needle filled with salt water is called a placebo. The people in the study were not told until after the study was over whether they had gotten the vaccine or the placebo. The people who had gotten the placebo had the chance to get the vaccine after the study was over.

Then, the vaccine was tested among people 12 to 15 years old from [date] to [date] in [places]. In the second study, the people in the study were 12 to 15 years old. ZZZ ADD MORE DETAILS
For every 10,000 people who were randomized to get two doses of the vaccine, 4 got Covid.
For every 10,000 people who were randomized to get two doses of salt water (placebo), 88 got Covid.
For every 10,000 people who were randomized to get two doses of the vaccine, 4 got Covid.

You may have already heard about this vaccine being 95% effective against getting Covid. This is because 4/88 = 5% and 100% - 5% = 95%. Vaccine effectiveness is the percent reduction in cases among people who got the vaccine compared to people who didn't get the vaccine.

c19vaxdaPfizerFr.vaxcontentdesc:
Le vaccin Pfizer/BioNTech a été autorisé par Santé Canada le 9 décembre 2020 pour les populations âgées de 16 ans et plus. Il a aussi été approuvé par Santé Canada le 5 mai 2021 pour les enfants âgés de 12 à 15 ans.

Il s'agit d'un vaccin à ARN messager (ARNm) à 2 doses. Le terme ARN messager signifie que le vaccin donne à votre corps des instructions pour fabriquer une partie du virus de la Covid-19 qui est inoffensive en soi. Votre corps apprend alors à combattre cette partie du virus. Si plus tard votre organisme se trouve confronté au virus complet, il saura comment détruire la partie qu'il reconnaît déjà. Privé de sa partie manquante, le virus ne peut pas survivre.

L'ARN messager ne persiste pas dans votre organisme. Le vaccin ne modifiera pas votre ADN.

"Incidence de la maladie Covid-19 pour 1 000 années-personnes suivies chez les participants sans indications d'une infection antérieure par le SRAS-CoV-2, jusqu'à sept jours après l'administration de la 2ème dose du vaccin".

c19vaxdaPfizerFr.vaxcontentdesc:
Le vaccin Pfizer/BioNTech est un vaccin à ARN messager (ARNm) administré en 2 doses. L'ARN messager permet au vaccin de donner à votre organisme des instructions sur la marche à suivre pour fabriquer une partie du virus de la Covid-19 (la "protéine de spicule" à l'extérieur du virus) qui est inoffensive. Votre corps va fabriquer ensuite cette partie inoffensive du virus. Puis, lorsque votre système immunitaire va être mis en contact avec cette nouvelle partie qu'il ne reconnaît pas comme faisant partie de vous, il cherchera à la détruire. Après avoir combattu cette partie une première fois, le système immunitaire, s'il rencontre le virus complet plus tard, saura comment détruire la partie qu'il reconnaît déjà. Privé de sa partie manquante, le virus ne peut pas survivre.

L'ARN messager ne persistera pas dans votre organisme. Une fois que votre système immunitaire aura appris à reconnaître le virus, il n'en aura plus besoin et l'éliminera. Le vaccin ne transformera pas votre ADN.

Il nécessite deux doses pour assurer votre pleine protection, car votre système immunitaire peut avoir besoin d'un rappel pour s'assurer qu'il reconnaît et sait comment combattre le virus.
Sans la vaccination, vous ne bénéficiez pas de cette protection renforcée.

The Pfizer vaccine was tested among those 16 years and older from [date] to [date] in [places]. The people in the study were people aged 16 years and older. The group included a broad mix of people. About half were male and about half were female. The group included people who were over 65 years old, who were pregnant, who had chronic illnesses, as well as many people who were younger, not pregnant, and who had no chronic illnesses. There were 36533 people in the study in total: 18196 who were randomly chosen to get two doses of the vaccine.

Then, the vaccine was tested among people 12 to 15 years old from [date] to [date] in [places]. In the second study, the people in the study were 12 to 15 years old. ZZZ ADD MORE DETAILS

c19vaxdaPfizerAdoEn.vaxcontentdesc:
The Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine was approved by Health Canada on December 9, 2020 for people 16 years old and older. It was approved by Health Canada on May 4, 2021 for children aged 12 to 15 years old.

It is a 2-dose messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine. Messenger RNA means the vaccine gives your body instructions to make a part of the Covid-19 virus that is harmless on its own. Your body then learns to fight off that part of the virus. If your body encounters the full virus later, it knows how to destroy the part it already recognizes. Without its missing part, the virus cannot survive.

Messenger RNA does not last in the body. The vaccine does not change your DNA.
"Incidence of Covid‑19 per 1,000 person‑years of follow‑up in participants without evidence of prior infection with SARS‑CoV‑2, up to seven days after the administration of Dose 2 of the vaccine"
About the vaccine & how it works

c19vaxdaPfizerAdoEn.vaxcontentdesc:
The Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine is a 2-dose messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine. Messenger RNA means the vaccine gives your body instructions for how to make a part of the Covid-19 virus (the "spike protein" on the outside of the virus) that is harmless on its own. Your body makes that harmless part of the virus. When your immune system runs into that new thing that it does not recognize as being part of you, your immune system figures out how to destroy the part. When the immune system has fought off the part once, if it encounters the full virus later, it knows how to destroy the part it already recognizes. Without its missing part, the virus cannot survive.

Messenger RNA does not last in the body. Once your immune system has learned to recognize the virus, it doesn't need the messenger RNA anymore. The vaccine does not change your DNA.

This vaccine requires two doses to provide full protection, because your immune system may need a reminder to make sure it recognizes and knows how to fight off the virus.
With no vaccine, you do not have this additional protection.

c19vaxdaModernaEn.vaxcontentdesc:
The Moderna vaccine was approved in Canada on December 23, 2020 for people 18 years old and older.

It can be stored at less extreme temperatures (-20 degrees C) and is therefore easier to transport to remote locations compared to the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine. It is currently available in all provinces and territories. It is a 2-dose messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine.

Messenger RNA means the vaccine gives your body instructions to make a part of the Covid-19 virus that is harmless on its own. Your body then learns to fight off that part of the virus. If your body encounters the full virus later, it knows how to destroy the part it already knows. Without its missing part, the virus cannot survive.

The vaccine does not change your DNA.

"symptomatic COVID-19 infection confirmed by Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) and by a clinical adjudication committee. The population for the analysis of the primary efficacy endpoint included participants who did not have evidence of prior infection with SARSCoV-2 through 14 days after the second dose."
About the vaccine & how it works

This vaccine requires two doses to provide full protection, because your immune system may need a reminder to make sure it recognizes and knows how to fight off the virus.

c19vaxda_vaccines.vaxdescen:
The Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine was approved in Canada on December 9, 2020 for people 16 years old and older. On May 5, 2021, the authorization was expanded to include individuals aged 12 to 15.

It must be kept extremely cold (-70 degrees C) and is therefore difficult to transport to remote locations. It is currently available in all provinces but not in any territories. It is a 2-dose messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine.

Messenger RNA means the vaccine gives your body instructions to make a part of the Covid-19 virus that is harmless on its own. Your body then learns to fight off that part of the virus. If your body encounters the full virus later, it knows how to destroy the part it already knows. Without its missing part, the virus cannot survive.

The vaccine does not change your DNA.
c19vaxda_vaccines.vaxcontraindicationsen: People who should not get this vaccine: those who are allergic to the active substance or to any ingredients in the vaccine. https://covid-vaccine.canada.ca/info/summary-basis-decision-detailTwo.html?linkID=SBD00510

c19vaxda_vaccines.vaxdescen:
The Moderna vaccine was approved in Canada on December 23, 2020 for people 18 years old and older.

It can be stored at less extreme temperatures (-20 degrees C) and is therefore easier to transport to remote locations compared to the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine. It is currently available in all provinces and territories. It is a 2-dose messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine.

Messenger RNA means the vaccine gives your body instructions to make a part of the Covid-19 virus that is harmless on its own. Your body then learns to fight off that part of the virus. If your body encounters the full virus later, it knows how to destroy the part it already knows. Without its missing part, the virus cannot survive.

The vaccine does not change your DNA.

The Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine was approved in Canada on February 26, 2021 for people 18 years old and older.

It can be stored at regular refrigerator temperatures (2-8 degrees C) and is therefore the easiest to store and transport of all the vaccines as of February 2021. It is currently available in all provinces and territories for people of specific ages (often people aged 40 and up or 45 and up.) It is a 2-dose adenovirus vector vaccine.

Adenovirus vector means the vaccine uses a harmless virus (not Covid) to get your body instructions to make a part of the Covid-19 virus that is harmless on its own. Your body then learns to fight off that part of the virus. If your body encounters the full virus later, it knows how to destroy the part it already knows. Without its missing part, the virus cannot survive.

The vaccine does not change your DNA.

The Janssen vaccine was approved in Canada on March 5, 2021 for people 18 years old and older.

It can be stored at regular refrigerator temperatures (2-8 degrees C) and is therefore one of the easiest to store and transport of all the vaccines so far. It is a 1-dose adenovirus vector vaccine.

Adenovirus vector means the vaccine uses a harmless virus (not Covid) to get your body instructions to make a part of the Covid-19 virus that is harmless on its own. Your body then learns to fight off that part of the virus. If your body encounters the full virus later, it knows how to destroy the part it already knows. Without its missing part, the virus cannot survive.

The vaccine does not change your DNA.
